title: Let's say I've completed a novel and gotten the copyright. Do I need to get a new copyright 'for the novel' if I add illustrations to each chapter of the novel, or will the old copyright cover this particular change? I own the illustrations. - Quora

response.answer_text: Adding illustrations constitute a major change in your book. You will have to get a new ISBN and copyright registration for an illustrated version of the book which is considered a “derivative work”. However, people do cheat. If you don’t make a very big deal out of adding illustrations to a newer layout, no one is probably going to notice. Though, you can’t then go adding this new information about illustrations to the previous copyright. So it will not come up in your current ISBN or Library of Congress listing that it is an illustrated book. You will also have to make sure to indicate a separate copyright for the illustrations in the new layout otherwise they can be copied. The original copyright will not cover illustrations not indicated by the copyright registration since they don’t appear in the manuscript you submitted.

You can register (get) copyright protections for artwork in one “batch” of 10 for a single fee. Check the copyright website for your country. That particular batch you submit, will then have copyright protection, regardless of where you put it or rearrange it. Here’s the U.S info for visual arts: Registration | U.S. Copyright Office If you publish your book, and months later - decide to change it with illustrations, however, - like C.D. Johnson said - you will definitely need new ISBNs.
You do not “get” a copyright. It’s granted automatically as soon as you put words into fixed form. Research at the Library of Congress or elsewhere.
